Ground black pepper also burns and gives off sparks. Powdered aluminum, magnesium, titanium, iron, steel, iron oxide and zinc are pretty reactive and will burn hot and bright, some giving off sparks. The more finely they are ground, the better the results. The shape of the particles also affect the results. Be careful if you try, and start with a small amount.

Im a pyrotechnican. We prepare our clothing that we will shoot the fireworks show in in a boric acid solution. Boric acid is a fire retardant.We soak our coveralls in the boric acid solution to make the clothing "less flammable". On the topic of your video, We also use coffee creamer and specifically "Cremora" powdered coffee creamer for special effects fireballs. We simply call them "Cremoras". 50 pounds of Cremora in a 55 gallon drum  is not at all uncommon. Makes a huge fireball.

Brick dust, Cement, fine powdered clay, powder from cutting stone, and, worst of all, Coal dust, are all highly explosive. The finer the dust, the more likely they are to combust.
A tube with a fan at the bottom, blowing through a filter to get the dust airborne, and a piezo-quartz spark igniter might get better results.

There have been flour mill explosions, energetic enough to damage the concrete storage silos, that were caused by workers neglecting to lubricate conveyor belt bearings.  The bearing eventually sparked, leading to the explosion.

When I was a kid the fire marshal would come to the school and do a demonstration. He had a box with hinged ends in the box was a spoon with a small hose attached. He would put flour in the spoon, light a candle and blow into the tube. There was a loud boom and the hinged ends would blow open. This was to demonstrate how grain elevators would explode, which was happening regularly at the time. Much like the custard factor that was mentioned in the video.

He also had a demonstration that included a piece of steel pipe welded to a steel plate. He would put a few drops of gasoline in the tube, put a stopper in it and shake it. He would then light a cigarette and uncork the tube and drop the cigarette into the tube. Again loud explosions are real entertaining to kids...
